Forum Post: 
Post title: Future maintenance and Moodle 4.5 compatibility
Post description: Hi everyone, We have been using the Journal plugin for many years, and since upgrading to Moodle 4.5 we have encountered several  issues. We noticed that there are multiple open pull requests on GitHub that contain fixes which have not yet been merged. For now, we plan to apply the relevant patches ourselves in order to keep the module running during this academic year. However, given the current lack of activity and the absence of an official release supporting Moodle 4.5, we are considering discontinuing the use of this module next year unless maintenance resumes. Could you please confirm whether there are any plans to continue maintaining this plugin or if it’s being phased out? It is a shame, because this module has been very valuable and interesting to use in our courses. Thank you for your work so far. Best, susana

Forum Post: 
Post title: Journals - Ability to Alphabetically Organize of Student Entries
Post description: It has been over a year since a forum entry with the same subject was started, so it is locked and cannot be commented on. I somehow missed the original question posed by Robin Latham, but in a private message yesterday, I provided her a partial solution, and it was so simple, I am mentioning it here so that others can implement it, too. She asked:  " Could we get a toggle to be able
to organize the journal entries by student last name rather than as it
is now by date of entry only?" Not a toggle, but a change to alphabetical order...In the lib.php file, look for: function journal_get_users_done($journal, $currentgroup) { It should be around line 702, depending on your version of journal. Just a few lines below that look for: $ sql .= " WHERE j.journal=? ORDER BY j.modified DESC"; Change it to: $sql .= " WHERE j.journal=? ORDER BY u.lastname ASC, u.firstname ASC"; This will cause both the users that are done and the users who have no entry, to be listed alphabetically when a teacher goes to the page generated by report.php. I have made a pull request to try and get this change into the Journal code at github. Robin also asked: "Also, if we could be able to download the entries, that would be nice." I do have a solution for this, but it is nowhere nearly as simple, requiring the addition of about 100 lines of code lib.php and nearly that many in report.php. Time permitting, I will try to add it to my github version of Journal, and will post here when it is available. Download entries is actually available in a new plugin I am developing, based on Journal, named, Diary. Over the years, I have seen numerous requests for a Diary plugin, and mine is similar (based off of) Journal with the added capability of giving the user a new blank entry, every time they go to edit on a new calendar day. Still have lots to do, but if anyone wants a look see, let me know via private message, and I will give access. Or you can git a, mostly current version, from the Diary master branch at my github account.

Post title: Journal for Moodle 2.7 released
Post description: Hi all, I've just added a new journal version in https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_journal for Moodle 2.7; the previous version was working as well, but this is the official release and the one I will be updating (only bug backports to 2.6). We need to specially thank AL Rachels ( https://moodle.org/user/profile.php?id=94615 ) for his contribution in this release as he removed all notices and debugging messages as well as converting the add_to_log() calls to the new events system ( http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Event_2 ) Thanks AL. Please, if you notice any new issue during these first days of testing and deployment comment about it here in the journal forums, on the tracker contrib component or on the github project page ( https://github.com/dmonllao/moodle-mod_journal ). Next step towards the code cleanup would be to write unit and acceptance tests for it so we will detect quickly when we are breaking something during the cleanup.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Journal for reflective writing assignments (instructor annotates and uses to prepare mini-lectures)?
Post description: I'm trying to find the best way in Moodle I can do the following: For each of the assigned readings (perhaps more than 25 in a semester) ask students to submit a reflective writing assignment. Deadline is something like three hours before my course, and I will use their contributions to prepare mini-lectures. Grading is simple (if they submit something reasonable, they get full credit). I only take marks off if they submit reading summaries (paraphrasing the content of what was read, not personal, not reflective). For the purpose of my mini-lecture preparation, I want to annotate their submissions, e.g., with comments on passages such as one can do in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, Adobe Acrobat, etc. I don't want to do this on hard copy in 2015. I'd like to be able to generate a word cloud using the content. I could have up to 40 students in two sections (80 students total) and I don't have a secretary to help me click! Looking at the Journal activity in Moodle, I think it comes up short on the annotation feature (at least based on the documentation I looked at, there seems to only be a form field for instructor feedback and a grade). I'm thinking of going with Assignments (there's bulk download of Word/PDF/etc.) documents although a Word cloud wouldn't be possible (that's not a show stopper). I'd appreciate feedback from the Moodle community regarding this approach. Thanks!

Post title: Journal performance
Post description: Hi all, I was wondering if some of you have been experiencing performance problems using the journal module or your administrators reported you any slow process related with the journal module. Forum Post: 
Post title: Journal Plugin for the Grade Me block
Post description: Hi Everyone, I have started using the Journal activity more and more for simple writing assignments for which I expect students to revise and resubmit their work on at least a weekly basis during a term. I really like the Grade Me block for alerts as to what needs to be graded, but it presently does not have a plugin for showing Journal entries that need grading. Last weekend, while laid up with another cold, a truly UNWANTED gift from my students, I managed to cobble together a working plugin that will do what's needed. The modification adds one folder, one file, and modifies one other file of Grade Me. Right now I am waiting on a reply from the Grade Me folks about getting a copy of the plugin to them. If anyone would like to try it out, I can provide a copy of it.  Just be forewarned, I have developed it for Moodle 2.7 versions of the Journal and Grade Me and have not had any time to test on any other versions. I might be able to do so next week, but no guarantees. It does work very nicely on Moodle 2.7, Moodle 2.8 beta, and Moodle 2.8 RC1. AL

Forum Post: 
Post title: Export Journal data to Excel
Post description: In case it's useful to anyone, here's what I've just used to export data from the Journal to an Excel spreadsheet (csv file). Run this query using phpmyadmin or similar. Adjust the fields as desired. The j.course is the id for the course (pull it from the url: http://moodle.<somewhere>.ca/course/view.php?id=493) SELECT journal journalid, j.name, j.intro, j.days, FROM_UNIXTIME(j.timemodified) journallastmodified, u.firstname, u.lastname, u.email, FROM_UNIXTIME(modified) usermodified, text, rating, entrycomment, teacher, FROM_UNIXTIME(timemarked) timemarked, mailed FROM mdl_journal_entries je INNER JOIN mdl_journal j ON j.id=je.journal INNER JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id=je.userid WHERE j.course=493 ORDER BY journal, modified Be sure to tell phpmyadmin to export as "CSV for MS Excel" and put a check in the field "Put fields names at first row".

Forum Post: 
Post title: Assignments are not the same as Journals
Post description: Since it appears Journals won't be supported in 1.7 anymore, it is with some reluctance I will probably be replacing my Journals with Assignments - they are not the same thing.  Just the name "Assignment" makes it sound like something the teacher is requiring, you do it, turn it in, then forget about it once it is done. What I liked about the Journal was the way the student could see all their entries on one page when they clicked on the link in the upper left (on my site).  This encouraged them to think of the Journal as a progression of thought and showed how their thinking or reflection was evolving as the course went on. It didn't look like a gradebook but rather was more personal - a journal that they "owned" rather than a series of assignments from the teacher. When they click on Assignments then it looks like a gradebook - each assignment is separate and they click multiple times in order to view each entry.  (And journal-like entries are mixed with other writing assigments). One of the harder things is to get student to connect the material earlier in the course to material later in the course and one of the uses of my journal was to get them to keep reflecting on this.  Sure I can ask them to do this using the Assignments, but the just the layout of it makes it more difficult and I don't think they feel the "ownership" that a Journal encourages. Bottom line - a series of Assignments is not a Journal - nor is a Blog unless they allow for making the Blog private.  [ Yes a peer-available or public Blog adds another dimension but depending on the course may not be appropriate.  ] Just venting here. Hacking Journal to work in 1.7 is not an option for me.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Daily Diary
Post description: Hello - I'm trying to set up a daily diary activity for my students.  I'd like it to be anonymous, but require them to write a certain number of words, at least five times per week. I'd like it to auto-grade to preserve anonymity.  Is this possible with the diary activity or another module? So far, my attempts have not worked.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, I'm not sure what you mean regarding, anonymous, but in a Diary activity, the teacher can ALWAYS see what the students write. Students can only see their OWN writing and do NOT have access to another students writing unless the students share the writing via some other means. e.g. Physically show them on their screen, or via copy and paste in an email message. You can set up automatic prompts that update at whatever time interval you desire. Each day is okay. Changing the required number of words each day is one of the automatic prompt options. You can also setup and use a, Gloassary of Common Errors (the actual name is optional), that is also accounted for in the auto rating suggested scoring. This makes it possible to enforce proper spelling so that the modern slang of such things as, u, instead of you, can be enforced. The autograding is actually only a suggested rating that the teacher can acept with one click of the mouse, and even if they apply the suggested rating they can always over ride it, and change the rating and feedback.
Comment 2: Thank you for the response. This is all very helpful. Unfortunately, I'm not sure the Diary activity will be useful for what I need. Basically, I'm trying to implement a daily writing journal for song writing students. I'd like to have these students write (anything) at least five times per week, and at least 200 words per entry. I'd like to reward them with a grade and I'd like Moodle to grade it automatically so that I DON'T have the need to look at it - thereby protecting the sanctity of the entries. Their writing would ideally be totally private, even from me as the instructor.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Change Journal Grading Points Possible After Submissions
Post description: Hello, I have an instructor who accidently made her journals worth 10 points, when they should be worth 3. We are looking for a way to edit and fix it but I don't see how. I know on some activity types you get the option to re-grade if there are changes made to grading, but I don't see that for journal activities . Do you know how?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: So far as I know, there is no way to do what you want in Moodle, as the capability is just not built into Journal. However, I will admit that I have changed a Journal from a Maximum grade of 100 to 10 and Grade to pass from 70 to 7, but had to do it directly in the database using phpMyAdmin . The biggest hurdle was to make sure I found the correct entry in the mdl_grade_items table. I then had to go and regrade every journal entry. I also did that in the database as it is quicker. Everything appeared to have been changed and updated correctly. WARNING: I do not recommend that you do this on a production Moodle site, but if you MUST make sure you back up your current data first. As an alternative, I know that at one time I was changing how much an activity was counted for in a final grade book calculation. Sorry to say I do not remember how I got in there to change that. What I do remember is just how much of a pain it was to do that. It probably was along the lines of putting the faulty journal in it's own category and then set how much that category counts towards the total grade.
Comment 2: Darn, since we're on a hosted version of Moodle editing the database is probably not something I can do and our host company will likely get cranky. I proposed something similar to the instructor in terms of the grade book solution you mentioned. I told her she could add a manual grade column and transcribe the correct grade there and take the original journal out of her calculations.
Comment 3: That's probably best. Could also create a new journal, with the correct grade setting, and then have all the students copy and paste their entry. Then just delete the old journal with the wrong settings.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Journals - Ability to Alphabetically Organize of Student Entries
Post description: It has been over a year since a forum entry with the same subject was started, so it is locked and cannot be commented on. I somehow missed the original question posed by Robin Latham, but in a private message yesterday, I provided her a partial solution, and it was so simple, I am mentioning it here so that others can implement it, too. She asked:  " Could we get a toggle to be able
to organize the journal entries by student last name rather than as it
is now by date of entry only?" Not a toggle, but a change to alphabetical order...In the lib.php file, look for: function journal_get_users_done($journal, $currentgroup) { It should be around line 702, depending on your version of journal. Just a few lines below that look for: $ sql .= " WHERE j.journal=? ORDER BY j.modified DESC"; Change it to: $sql .= " WHERE j.journal=? ORDER BY u.lastname ASC, u.firstname ASC"; This will cause both the users that are done and the users who have no entry, to be listed alphabetically when a teacher goes to the page generated by report.php. I have made a pull request to try and get this change into the Journal code at github. Robin also asked: "Also, if we could be able to download the entries, that would be nice." I do have a solution for this, but it is nowhere nearly as simple, requiring the addition of about 100 lines of code lib.php and nearly that many in report.php. Time permitting, I will try to add it to my github version of Journal, and will post here when it is available. Download entries is actually available in a new plugin I am developing, based on Journal, named, Diary. Over the years, I have seen numerous requests for a Diary plugin, and mine is similar (based off of) Journal with the added capability of giving the user a new blank entry, every time they go to edit on a new calendar day. Still have lots to do, but if anyone wants a look see, let me know via private message, and I will give access. Or you can git a, mostly current version, from the Diary master branch at my github account.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Ooops! My wife was after me to go do something, and I forgot to include one other change that alphabetizes the users who have NOT made an entry. Do the change listed above. Then, in the file report.php down around line 158, look for this line of code: $users = get_users_by_capability($ context , 'mod/journal:addentries', '', '', '', '', $groups); Change it to this: $users = get_users_by_capability($context, 'mod/journal:addentries', '', $sort='lastname ASC, firstname ASC', '', '', $groups); Sorry for not catching the omission while making the first post.

Comment 1: The only way you could do what you describe with the Journal plugin would be to have a new Journal activity each day, with it's 'Day's available' set for 1 days. There is no way to limit their access to just part of their entry.

Post title: Journal for reflective writing assignments (instructor annotates and uses to prepare mini-lectures)?
Post description: I'm trying to find the best way in Moodle I can do the following: For each of the assigned readings (perhaps more than 25 in a semester) ask students to submit a reflective writing assignment. Deadline is something like three hours before my course, and I will use their contributions to prepare mini-lectures. Grading is simple (if they submit something reasonable, they get full credit). I only take marks off if they submit reading summaries (paraphrasing the content of what was read, not personal, not reflective). For the purpose of my mini-lecture preparation, I want to annotate their submissions, e.g., with comments on passages such as one can do in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, Adobe Acrobat, etc. I don't want to do this on hard copy in 2015. I'd like to be able to generate a word cloud using the content. I could have up to 40 students in two sections (80 students total) and I don't have a secretary to help me click! Looking at the Journal activity in Moodle, I think it comes up short on the annotation feature (at least based on the documentation I looked at, there seems to only be a form field for instructor feedback and a grade). I'm thinking of going with Assignments (there's bulk download of Word/PDF/etc.) documents although a Word cloud wouldn't be possible (that's not a show stopper). I'd appreciate feedback from the Moodle community regarding this approach. Thanks!

Post title: Journal performance
Post description: Hi all, I was wondering if some of you have been experiencing performance problems using the journal module or your administrators reported you any slow process related with the journal module. Pau Ferrer contributed a patch improving the performance of the module when viewing the number of journal entries and I've contributed a few more improving the cron process that sends emails. I would prefer to include those changes only in master (or also 2.8 as it has just been released) but I am not feeling like backporting it to 2.7 and 2.6 as the changes have not been properly tested in real environments, only in testing environments but I would reconsider it if some of you are experiencing important performance issues. Please, comment if that's the case. Thanks in advance.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David, Personally, I have not noticed any performance problems with the Journal add-on, but my Moodle site is quite small and I never have more than 17 student journals being viewed at one time. Content is just short 5 paragraph essays of 21 sentences. Thanks for your continued work on this module, AL
Comment 2: Thansk David, We would appreciate to have this enhacements on performance in Moodle 2.6. We discovered this problem in a huge  Moodle: +2k courses, +38000 users... +150 users per course (the average is 23 users per course). With a journal with more than 150 entries, the function that calculates the number of entries does arround 700 DB queries (4-5 queries per entry)... It costs 180-200 seconds to render the entire page. Now, with that improvements it cost only 40 queries and arround a second to render. We would definetely try the cron improvements in this production site and we will try to report the results. Cheers!
Comment 3: Thanks for replying AL and Pau

The next Journal module version for 2.9 will include all the performance improvements.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tracy, Yes, Journal 2.7.2 will work with Moodle 2.8. About three weeks ago I discovered that most versions of Journal (including 2.6) have one small bug in the journal lib.php file if you are using Journal set for Grade > None and with debugging turned on. The bug is a notice that an offset is not set and is caused by checking to see if a grade has been overridden in the gradebook...but no entry is in the gradebook because the Journal is set for no grade. A couple of days ago I came up with a fix that will most likely be in the next version along with a new feature I've come up with that posts a notice that a journal entry needs to be regraded if the student makes changes to an entry that has already been graded. The upshot of it all is that it will not hurt to go ahead and use Journal 2.7.2 with Moodle 2.8. Tonight I will finish pushing that last fix up to my github account and you can get an updated copy with the fixes, if you would like to. HTH , AL

Post description: Moodle 2.5. : When I view students´ entries , I get this error: Retroalimentación: Notice: Undefined offset: 0 in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Notice: Trying to get property of non-object in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Notice: Trying to get property of non-object in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Notice: Undefined offset: 0 in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Notice: Trying to get property of non-object in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Notice: Trying to get property of non-object in /home/moodle.eoivh.cat/moodle/mod/journal/lib.php on line 738 Thanks in advance Martin
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Martin, This message is thrown PHP but it is not a fatal error which blocks the page execution, it should be solved but that kind of messages should not be displayed to users as information about your system (like paths) is exposed to them. This can be managed through debug and debugdisplay settings (you can look for them in the site administration block) http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Debugging All production sites should disabled debugdisplay.

Post title: Moodle 2.3: journal textbox is blank when editing
Post description: Hi, We updated to Moodle 2.3 (from 2.2). It seems that the journal module now clears all text when students click on the edit button. If a student wants to edit text, sees the blank text field and hits "save changes" the students will lose all work done to this point and only any new text entered will be visible. Does anyone else experience this issue? Regards Anatol
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Anatol, Thanks for reporting the problem, I've created an issue in the tracker ( http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/CONTRIB-3807 ) and solved the problem. You can download or fetch from upstream the last version of the module. Thanks, David
Comment 2: Hi David, great! Thank you so much for your very quick response and for fixing this issue. The journal now works as expected on Moodle 2.3. Cheers! Anatol
Comment 3: I downloaded the leatest version, installed it but I still get a empty box when I try to edit text. Journal: 2012072600 Moodle 2.3.1+ (Build: 20120802) Do I have to do anything more? Best regards Philipp
Comment 4: We have Moodle build 2.3.1+ (20120809), and journal module build 2012072600.  The reported problem is happening to us as well.  Did a recent core code update break the journal (again)?
Comment 5: Hi Philipp and James, Thanks for reporting the problem, it was solved a month ago but I forgot to update the plugins page package. You can also download the latest version (Build: 2012072900) from the plugins page
Comment 6: Works perfect... Thank you! Best regards Philipp
Comment 7: Yes!  It looks to me like it is indeed fixed.  Thank you so much for posting!

Post title: System-level teachers appear in Journal assignment list
Post description: Hi, Using 2.1.2. Any idea why two teachers who have system-level teacher roles appear in the list of Journal respondents, alongside the regular list of students?  These two teachers are not associated in any way with the course, but the Journal tool thinks they are. Thoughts?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Glenn, If I remember ok the users list is based on the mod/journal:addentries capability
Comment 2: Thanks for the reply.  That complicates a situation on my end where I need some users to be system level teachers for other reasons.
Comment 3: Hi, You can remove the 'journal:addentries' capability of the system-level teacher role but the course-level teachers will also be affected... (unless you add course-level exceptions, which I suppose is annoying to manage)
Comment 4: Yes, it would be annoying.  Basically, my problem stems from an inconsistency/bug regarding Moodle permissions in another area completely, but which forces me to assign them instructor roles at the System level (see http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-31146 ).  Because I have to assign instructors at the system level in order to workaround the other permissions bug, I get trapped by system-level issues throughout Moodle (so far it's been managable).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Journal in Moodle 2 does not give feedback
Post description: Before I report this as a bug I thought I would ask if anyone else has come across this problem. I have added Journal to a Moodle 2 install and have two teachers using Journal with a group of students. The students have made entries and the teachers have given them feedback. The students cannot see the feedback from their teachers. The course settings have "show gradebook to students". The journal settings I made "no grade" and that is what the teachers see when they write in the feedback. They cannot give a grade. When you edit the journal settings it shows as if grade is set to "100". Help? Is this a bug I should report or is there something else I should check first? Thanks.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there The Journal module has been deprecated, which means it is no longer a part of core Moodle and hasn't been since 1.9 With the improvements to the online text assignment, the advice being given is to move instructors over to using that instead. There is a developer working on the gradebook-Journal connection. You may want to contact him. Here is a link to the issue tracker for the project: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/CONTRIB/component/10880 Cheers KerryJ
Comment 2: Hi Tabitha,

It seems a bug (or a pair). Thanks for reporting it will be fixed tomorrow
Comment 3: Thanks David. Should I put it in tracker or will you? Thank you.
Comment 4: Answering my own question... Journal activities edition always shows the default grade, 100 - http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/CONTRIB-2869
Comment 5: Hi Tabitha, there were two different problems, the other one is that the feedback is not shown on "no grade" journals, I created another tracker entry ( CONTRIB-2871 ) for that. You can upgrade to the latest version from CVS since now, or wait until tomorrow or saturday to download through the Modules & Plugins link Thanks for the bug report!

Post title: Students allowed to view ALL Journal entries
Post description: How do you allow students to view ALL journal entries in a (read-only) permission for a specific Course that they're enrolled in?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Elizabeth, I don't know how to do that except to give all students permission to act as teachers in the journal activity. You would need to read up on changing the role permissions in Moodle to do that. If you want all students to see the entries, I recommend using the Forum Module instead.
Comment 2: Or you could use a wiki.
Comment 3: Hi Elizabeth, You should be able to override the member permissions so they can see all the journal entries. However, I don't see a Journal section in the Override area. So, it may be a little trial and error to find out which permission to change. I am actually trying to figure out how to override the non editing teachers ability to see all journal entries. Our journals are kept private for our members but we have someone overseeing that area for questions, etc. If you click Assign Roles then override permissions

Forum Post: 
Post title: Export Journal data to Excel
Post description: In case it's useful to anyone, here's what I've just used to export data from the Journal to an Excel spreadsheet (csv file). Run this query using phpmyadmin or similar. Adjust the fields as desired. The j.course is the id for the course (pull it from the url: http://moodle.<somewhere>.ca/course/view.php?id=493) SELECT journal journalid, j.name, j.intro, j.days, FROM_UNIXTIME(j.timemodified) journallastmodified, u.firstname, u.lastname, u.email, FROM_UNIXTIME(modified) usermodified, text, rating, entrycomment, teacher, FROM_UNIXTIME(timemarked) timemarked, mailed FROM mdl_journal_entries je INNER JOIN mdl_journal j ON j.id=je.journal INNER JOIN mdl_user u ON u.id=je.userid WHERE j.course=493 ORDER BY journal, modified Be sure to tell phpmyadmin to export as "CSV for MS Excel" and put a check in the field "Put fields names at first row".

Post title: Journals and feedback lost after permissions change
Post description: Hi, Recently on our Moodle site (version 1.7) there was a problem with role permissions being changed but we put them back to the way they were previously. But for journal entries and the feedback given to them, now students cannot see these. But the grade is still recorded in the grades section so that is pretty much all they can see of previous journal entries. Also the student does not seem to have the ability to start a journal entry, all they see is the journal question posted. Did one of the permissions not get put back to the way it should be? What permission would be affecting this journal problem? Any help would be greatly appreciated!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Laura,  Small world eh?  Found your post by searching Google for this problem (sigh)! Shawn
Comment 2: I met the same problem, even without changing the rights of the users. I hope, somebody can explain this. We work with moodle 1.7
Comment 3: Hi 24 hours later, I found at least a workauround: I gave the teacher, that lost the journal-entries, the rights of an administrator in our moodle-installation. In her classroom, I set her role to course-creator. With this combination, she should be able to see the journals of her students and stay a member of her classroom simultaneously (if her role in the classroom is set to administrator, she is no longer member of the class!). It is important to control, that the person, wich is course-creator, is NOT inscribed simultaneously as teacher or student, if so, the system won't work! I would be glad to hear about a solution, that avoids the need of distributing administration-rights so freely ... Heini Trümpy
Comment 4: This does make sense as I recently gave this instructor administrator rights.  I will add her as a course creator for the class involved (sigh...she is in several classes!) and see if that has a positive effect. Will let you know.  Shawn

Comment 5: Nigel, I haven't found a quick fix or a setting for journal e-mail notification, but here's how I save a lot of time when checking for new journal entries: 1) Click "Journals" in your " Activities " block. OR 2) Click "Reports" in your "Administration" block. Select the date you want to check, click the drop-down arrow by "All activities" and select "Journals," click "Get these logs," and any journal entries on that date will be listed. Hope this helps. If anyone discovers a setting, please let me know too. Cindi

Forum Post: 
Post title: Assignments are not the same as Journals
Post description: Since it appears Journals won't be supported in 1.7 anymore, it is with some reluctance I will probably be replacing my Journals with Assignments - they are not the same thing.  Just the name "Assignment" makes it sound like something the teacher is requiring, you do it, turn it in, then forget about it once it is done. What I liked about the Journal was the way the student could see all their entries on one page when they clicked on the link in the upper left (on my site).  This encouraged them to think of the Journal as a progression of thought and showed how their thinking or reflection was evolving as the course went on. It didn't look like a gradebook but rather was more personal - a journal that they "owned" rather than a series of assignments from the teacher. When they click on Assignments then it looks like a gradebook - each assignment is separate and they click multiple times in order to view each entry.  (And journal-like entries are mixed with other writing assigments). One of the harder things is to get student to connect the material earlier in the course to material later in the course and one of the uses of my journal was to get them to keep reflecting on this.  Sure I can ask them to do this using the Assignments, but the just the layout of it makes it more difficult and I don't think they feel the "ownership" that a Journal encourages. Bottom line - a series of Assignments is not a Journal - nor is a Blog unless they allow for making the Blog private.  [ Yes a peer-available or public Blog adds another dimension but depending on the course may not be appropriate.  ] Just venting here. Hacking Journal to work in 1.7 is not an option for me.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi, Maureen, Actually, you convinced me! Regards, Art
Comment 2: I agree with whole my heart: nice that Moodle becomes so spohistacated, and yes I begged for that... but do not forget the normal teachers who still pick up the mouse when the manual says "move the mouse to top right of the screen" or asking you what that funny orange rss means... They need simple flat clear modules for a start. using these moduls they will grow in their needs then they will understand all these options (and again next year new teachers - new in Moodle - will arrive..)
Comment 3: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Journal Shows All Students, Not Just Class Roster
Post description: We recently import 300+ students into Moodle 1.7 using the CSV upload function. All went well until we pulled up a journal assignment, and found that Moodle now lists all 300+ students are participants, rather than just the members of a class. The same thing happens with the Scheduler module. This affects both existing courses and new courses created after the import. We're not seeing any PHP or MySQL errors from Moodle (at least dumped to the screen; I need to look at the error log and see what might be there). Any thoughts on what might be causing this behavior? Has anyone else seen it?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: To answer my own question, this problem was caused by the deprecated function "get_course_students" now found in /lib/deprecatedlib.php. It's query was formatted in such a way as to return all students who hadn't logged into Moodle yet. The bug is documented here, as is the fix: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-7592 This bug was fixed in the Moodle 1.7.1 source code.

Post title: Seeing student journal entries
Post description: Hi all, I'm probably overlooking some simple setting, but... I plan to use student journal entries as a means of encouraging students to reflect on the day's activities . However, on my live site, and on a test site, I have made entries into journals, but when I go in as administrator, I cannot see them. The only entries that show up are the ones I have made. According to the page, none of the students has made journal entries, even though I have done so on the test site by logging in as different students and making entries. Anyone any ideas?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you select the journal as a teacher (or administrator), there should be a link at the top right of the screen, under the breadcrumb list for "View 24 journal entries", or whatever the number is.
Comment 2: Hi Miles, Yes, I had that link, but no entries showed up, even though I had made them myself on the test site. Eventually, a couple of hours later, they came through. I would have expected them to appear once the "editing time" had expired. It seems to take some time for entries to eventually appear. I have set my editing time to 1 minute, but still, it is taking some time for entries to appear in the administrator's view. I don't mind, once this is normal, but I need to be sure I will eventually be able to see all journal entries. Thanks, Matt
Comment 3: Matt, I have the same trouble with viewing student entries.  They haven't appeared even after a couple of hours.  It says that there is no entry, but when I click on the 'picture' (smiling face) next to the section where it says no entry for the student, I am able to see it by going through a round about way of viewing the student's activities. How did you change the editing time? Is that the same as changing the length of days that the journal is posted. It seems the shortest time is one day. How did you change it to one minute? Please let me know the quickest way to solve this problem.  Thank you for taking the time to help. Ron
Comment 4: Hi Ron, See my other posting to this forum: "I continued with my testing, and the journal entries I made never made it into my (adminstrator/teacher) view. Then, I had call to restart my machine for a different reason, and when I logged back into the test course, all the missing journal entries were visible to me. " After that restart, I've never had a problem since. To change the editing time, for me (still using 1.4.4), it is Administration...configuration....variables, then put your chosen value in for maxeditingtime. Regards, Matt
Comment 5: I continued with my testing, and the journal entries I made never made it into my (adminstrator/teacher) view. Then, I had call to restart my machine for a different reason, and when I logged back into the test course, all the missing journal entries were visible to me. Matt

Forum Post: 
Post title: Errors upgrading Journal module
Post description: I ran into errors when upgrading to the latest development version. I was upgrading from a version from about March 10th, to the latest version in the CVS . I ran into the following errors when it did the journal module upgrade. It says there are errors in the SQL syntax. Is this a serious problem? How can it be fixed? journal module needs upgrading ( mysql ): SELECT * FROM mdl_journal WHERE introformat = '3'
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It's a bug in cvs:/moodle/lib/wiki_to_markdown.php which converts all texts using the obsolete 'Wiki-like" formatting to Markdown, now fixed in CVS. Did you use the Wiki-like format a lot? Those entries may look a little odd now because of the failed upgrade. To fix it, when you get the new code, you can try decrementing the number in the database ->modules->journal->version and re-upgrading.
Comment 2: Thanks, Martin!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using Journals for Personal Development Planning
Post description: At Glasgow Uni, Moodle is currently being used in English Language modules. We are looking at introducing personal development planning for all students and were wondering whether anyone had any experience of using the journal as a personal development planning tool? We would envisage the journal being used by students to record reflections about their learning on the course and perhaps they would be prompted/asked questions at key points in the course by their tutor? It wouldn't be graded. Has anyone tried this and if so would you share your experience with us? Thanks : )
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: On a course "Coping with change" (New Curiosity Shop) I've used the journal, with trigger questions such as "record your reflections on this in your journal", or "to what extent does this model reflect your experience? put your comments in your journal". It seems to work very well.
Comment 2: Thanks Joanna, Can you tell me, do you assess or track the entries? If not, what do you think makes the students complete the journal and what is the uptake of it as a tool by students?
Comment 3: There is a place to give feedback, so I give general comments. At the moment I'm working with a very small group - so it's easy just to read what's written and be supportive (or challenging if that's what they want) I see it as very much their stuff, as I would in a f2f course when students were working on their personal development. I suppose they complete it because the trigger questions interest them and they think they ought to as it's part of the course. Assessment is problematic: should we assess someone else's personal development? and if so how? I would prefer that they assess themselves against a framework developed collaboratively.
Comment 4: Please come and talk! (GUIDE - Glasgow University Initiative in Distance Education - just down the road from you?! - NB we currently support any Moodler in the University - especially but not exclusively distance ed. staff and learners). Moodle will easily facilitate the sort of PDP work you may have in mind - yes, via Journals but also via other 'features' - if you want to ensure learner-learner/s interaction and extend from a tutor-learner one-way interaction - so, via Dialogue, Forum etc etc.  Do come and talk - it sounds very do-able and relatively straightforward. The great joy of Moodle (and a key reason why the U of Glasgow has recently adopted it as its centrally supported VLE) is its inherent flexibility, its potential to afford a range of learning opportunitities (such as PDP here) espec. those premised in soc. constructivist learning and support, and its relative ease of use (thereby affording learning enabled not driven by technology).   A further plus for moodle.org is its potential to enable folk in the same institution to communicate! It would be good to hear from anyone else using Moodle for PDP and I seem to recall seeing some messages about it - will use 'search' and see!
Comment 5: There's a posting by Ger T (re. a CETIS newsletter) at http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=13641 and from there to the WS4RL (Web Services for Reflective Learning) site at http://cetis.ac.uk:8080/frameworks/learning_domain_services/personal_development_management/ws4rl/view

Post title: Students cannot make entries to a journal
Post description: Hi, I have the following situation: A teacher adds a journal to a course, the course's students can see the journal but have no possibility to make an entry. I can't find out, what's wrong. Did I accidently change a wrong setting somewhere? If I can't solve this problem, I can't use journals at all..! thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: What is the closing date of the journal in the settings?  If it is the past, then the journal is closed and entries can no longer be made.  You need to modify the closing date to open it up. Tim.

Forum Post: 
Post title: proper use of a Journal
Post description: I am considering using the Journal as a means for a) the student to reflect on they key items of the unit (a total of 11 units), and b) practise their writing skills (paragraph and sentence structure, grammar, etc). I initially intended for the students to submit a 500 word (2 pages) summary of each unit.  My questions are: Is 500 words too long for Journal entries and can I edit their entries (similiar to editing a Word document) to provide feedback on their writing skills? Thanks, Jim
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Jim, The journal doesn't have the capability of editing like Word, but it is a useful way to give quick and frequent feedback about writing and about ideas. I like having students revise their journals through the week with frequent suggestions from me. Giving developing journals one minute of attention here and there, saves enormous amounts of editing/grading/reading time for the teacher at the conclusion of the process. If you REALLY need an "in-line" editing function, you can spend the time to login as the student, and edit the journal in a different font color (using the HTML editor), though the logging can get tedious with big classes. The absolute proper use of a journal is probably to have the student reflect and revise on his own for a period of time. Then the teacher provides feedback. For this functionality, no module is better. But, hey, this software is incredibly flexible, so I don't think it is wrong to re-imagine its use to fit your situation. best, Tom
